name: Darwinia
description: Combining fast-paced action with strategic battle planning, Darwinia features a novel and intuitive control mechanism, a graphical style ripped from 80's retro classics like Tron and Defender, and a story concerning a tribe of nomadic sprites trapped in a modern 3D world.
minimum_requirements: Recommended: Windows XP, 600MHz CPU, 128MB RAM, DX7 based video card

reviews.review_text: I don't know what compelled me to even buy this since I can't stand RTS games generally, but it didn't take long before Darwinia became one of my all-time favorites. Something in the way it's presented just made sense to me, and I found the context to be especially endearing.  Part of what really appealed to me was how simple and straightforward everything was: soldiers shoot stuff, engineers build stuff, etc. Even the upgrade options, in the context of file updates (v2.0), made everything feel more accessible. The game code is mercifully stable for an 'indie' game and I found myself wasting hours defeating every last enemy and making sure that every uninhabited piece of land was repopulated. I frequently found myself rooting for individual scouts and soldiers that bravely out-maneuvered their enemies. It really says something about a game that can make you feel so attached to its literal pixels.  The excellent score and sound effects coupled with the game's relaxingly retro aesthetic have proven great for replayability, making Darwinia a world I'm happy to revisit often. 9/10.

If you like the retro-graphics, don't mind micromanaging dumb units in RTS as the primary gameplay, and get this on sale (I got it for like $1.45 with Multiwinia during the 2014 Exploration sale) then you'll probably like it fine. Otherwise you probably won't.  The game definitely pays tribute to Tron and other such digital-grid visual experiences. Regarding Tron, anybody else notice the bombers for airstrikes in this game are called 'Invaders'? Heh.

Introversion are very clever and really understand retro gaming. This is an arcade game in 3D in which you must save the virtual world 'Darwinia' from the spread of a computer virus. If this was how regular antivirus programs worked it would be easy to keep the entire internet clean.

In most RTS games, resource-gathering and military power are two mostly separate things. In Darwinia, your resources are actually the souls of dead units and you need to harvest them soon after you kill them.   This choice between harvesting and military is very dynamic. You can and have to change your tactics fast to deal with the situation. You have a low maximum number of units but there is no build time. However, you can only build at certain locations, so waiting time depends on where the battle is taking place.  Third, micro-management is quite different from what you're used to: You don't just click to attack, you decide exactly where your soldiers shoot. Macro-management is really narrative-driven. Levels have very different goals with each other and winning feels more like solving a puzzle than managing and allocating resources.   Darwinia is a weird little game, it's one of those things that broaden your horizons. That's why it shouldn't be missed.

The retro design depends on the players taste but for the game, it represents the birthplace of the Darwinians. Even bought it on Steam Sale. Woohoo! Merry Christmas.

I LOVE this game, it seemed like such an odd premise at first, as the tutorial explained how to play, it seemed even more odd, but ti was so engaging, it had me hooked from the first proper level, the gameplay is fun, the visuals, unique, and the story, whilst being minimal, is excellent for the game, it immersed me so well. If you a fane of strategy games, this game is an excellent twist on the genre.
Great game, very experimental approach to strategy. Nice mix of macro-strategy and third person action. Not to mention its soundtrack is completely amazing.

One of my personal favorites. I dearly love Introversion software for their unique and new games. Darwinia focuses on a virtual world on the server of Dr. Sepulveda, with little green people figures called Darwinians. As you find out, they're under a viral attack and desperately need your help to survive. Dr. Sepulveda's life work is on the line, and it's up to you to use the programs he gives you, or can find, to destroy the virus and save a breakthrough in AI programming. The gameplay is simple, easy to understand, and while the visuals aren't 'photorealistic' they are perfectly fitted for the theme of the game, and very Tron like, lending it a perfect visual capacity. You can upgrade your various programs to greater effectiveness, and guide the little Darwinians to help them get their world back. It's incredibly fun, and the story is quite compelling.
A minimalist world but engaging. I felt very protective of my little green icons. There were times that I would restart a level if I had unacceptable losses.

From the gameplay to the soundtrack and graphics, this game is beautifully designed. It has a low file-size, an extremely pleasing retro artstyle, and intuitive and fun gameplay. The setting and atmosphere are perfect, the difficulty is perfect, and the story manages to be interesting and compelling despite being given almost no time for exposition of any kind.   I have played through this game many times now - even more than my playtime suggests since it can run on a toaster and so is perfect for old laptops with no internet connection - and every time I find it entertaining and challenging. For the price, this is an amazing purchase, and I wish Introversion would give it the sequel it sorely deserves. No, Multiwinia does not count.  One protip if you play this though: Don't use the GUI. Hotkeys are significantly better.

I personally liked the game.I beat the whole story in 13 hours (that is killing every enemy on the map not just completeing each objective) and enjoyed every bit of it! Frist i'll tell you what i liked about the game: The story, the art style, and gameplay! I haven't read much about the story in other reviews but i like it and thats all ill say. The art style is supposed to look like you are in a computer world(kinda like tron) so it is really simple but kinda 'cute' or cartoony. The game play is what everyone is talking about so first the problems. I couldn't unplug my headset while playing the game or else an error would appear and it would crash. The Darwinians are like cattle where they move in straight lines but if you use officers correctly then you're fine. a bug happened where i couldn't build anything but restarting the game fixed that. The first mission (not prolouge) is really boring and that deterrs many people. Positive: Alot of game time for 1$ (currently 13hrs) I thought the sound effects were funny. Some stratiegic thought and tactics do go into this game. (its not just run at each other, get more units and repeat) You unlock something at the end that increases the amount of time you could play it! ;) Nice soundtrack There is alot more that i like but i must go to the counter arguments or problems. Dubhe said '- Units with bizarre controls, like: --- Left click to select --- Left click to move --- Left click and hold to to special action 1 --- Left click and hold near the unit to do special action 2' I don't know what game he was playing but you do use left click to select and move but you hold right click to shoot and while holding right click if you left click they do their special. Dubhe also said '--- Don't worry, though, because your units will randomly exit and reenter the turret every couple of seconds! Even during battle! --- Also, you can't control where the turret fires! And it does damage to friendly units! --- And, it's inexplicably easy for enemy units to kick your guys out and take control of the turret!' My units never reentered and exited turrets unless the units inside the turret were killed. You can control where the turret fires but darwinians have to be inside and your units can also kick enemy out of turrets too. (kinda funny when they just keep kicking each other.) XD Lidion45 said 'Unable to select more than one unit at once?!?! Clunky controls for moving units Units don't fire by themselves, yet randomly play the shooting sound when you're not looking? Bullets bouncing on uneven terrain makes shooting very awkward given most of the map is mountainous' Yes the first is true but i didn't have a problem with it. My units did fire by themselves (maybe he/she didn't have darwinian reasearched to level 2?) Bullets do bounce on terrain and sometimes that got annoying so i avoided terrain like that.  Overall i loved the game even though it does have its little bugs and problems but wouldn't buy it for the 10$ (or 20$ for both) I would get them on sale so you get both games for 1.30$.  (No offence to the other reviews I just used yours as counter arguments.)
Darwinia's tiresome control scheme and extremely slow pace turned me off for good after two separate attempts to get into it.
This is a really solid game and a lot of fun if you can get past the ancient graphics.
I had to buy this game twice before I remembered that I hate RTS games.

This is an interesting though fairly simple RTS type game with abstract graphics. It's not bad but it failed to totally suck me in. I got it as part of a Prison Architect package, so it's not a bad bonus. Worth checking out if you get a similarly good deal on it.

However, by the time I got to later points I was simply sick of micromanaging individuals and sick of fighting with the unintelligent AI underlying my little darwnians.

A casual strategy game where failure is an inconvenience at worst. You march your little crude soldiers, or herd native darwinians, in the fight to reclaim a virtual world infested with hostilered programs to reclaim a meek programmer's flimsy AI experiment. Be wary of leveling, as you must highlight the category to rank up as you play.

This is an amazingly addictive game. The idea that a sandbox with a story could be so engaging was quite a surprise, to say the least. The world of Darwinia is a cross between a type of 8bit Tron and Company of Heroes.

I adore this game, but it's very hard to describe without making it sound dry and boring. It'sa combination of puzzle-solving, strategic thinking and open warfare as you control a battle against an aggressive computer virus on several fronts. Beautiful retro graphics, great audio fx, and enough content to keep you fighting for hours and hours. I'm just two battles from the end, and when I finish I'll be starting over.
This is a wonderful time sink. Like RTS games? Give this a shot.

I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this game. Its well made and we'll polished with minimal glitches. The only glitch I've encountered really is just an annoyance and not really game breaking, when the 'eggs' land in water and hatch and there's just enemies stuck in the water, it can get annoying and your engineers will die when going over the water where the enemies are and you can't really kill the enemies there.  Honest score: 8.5/10 Plenty of fun, but I can defiantly see that it may not be for everyone.
Love this game, but wish I could figure out how to save my mods status from login to login  And yes, it's true I only wrote and then updated this review to get badges.!

Top-down realtime strategy game that takes place in Darwinia, a virtual world that Darwinians live in. Darwinia was taken over by a virus, and it's up to you to control different programs to wipe out the virus, rebuild the population, and connect the world back together.  I love this game and I love it's story. I have played it all the way through multiple times, which I never usually do with story-based games. Once you complete the game (which does take a decent amount of time), you are able to create your own worlds and share them with others to complete. What's also interesting is that after every location, there always seems to be a new mechanic that is introduced, always keeping the game fresh and more difficult.  There is another game called Multiwinia that is a multiplayer version, though I haven't really played it too much.

I must admit I wasn't sure what to expect here, but this is definitely one of the better games I've played in a while. The gameplay itself varies a lot, but overall it controls kind of like an RTS game.  Couldn't put it down until I finished it.
Solid gameplay and a pretty decent story great if you have a few extra bucks and want a nice well made and supported game
The greatest game you never played. It is the most unique and refreshing RTS that I have played in a while.
Pretty fun, get one of the packs though.
Really good indie game.

I love what this game did to my conception of modern computer gaming. Darwinia gave me hope, it helped me realize that I'm not the only one who looks back nostalgically on old games and wishes that the focus would not carry on soullessly into shallow graphics obsessions and endless fps sequels. This game takes the best of arcade-fashion gameplay and adds the 3rd dimension. The first time I saw this game I was fascinated by how simultaneously old and new it looked.  On top of that, this game is fun as hell to play. I care about these freaking computer shapes. I feel sad when they die. I feel happy when they win. The battles in this game can become massive and the death toll can become unconscionable. This is thanks to the story, which beautifully gives life to simple pixellated shapes in such an incredible manner, it makes the whole thing almost believable.  Oh, also. The soundtrack is FREAKING AWESOME. Really. The soundtrack. Is. Awesome. If you haven't played this yet, and consider yourself an avid gamer, please do yourself a favor and buy. I am going to overstep my credibility and label this the original indie game.
Helped me establish my plot for cyber-world domination  10/10

Outstanding! This game has this old-school geek feeling mixed in with nostalgia (like in the recent Tron movie) and this provides quite unique atmoshpere and gameplay. Alas, there is awful pathfinding and unit creation/selection interface, but it is really minor point from my side. Recently I just realised that I have all the games from Introversion software here in Steam - surprising! This includes Darwinia, Defcon, Multiwinia, Uplink and Prison Architect... what a collection of really unique gems. Anyway, this game is inspiring.

Picked up Darwinia and Multiwinia for $1.50 during winter sale. It's been a fun 20 hours. Great game., very unique which I appreciate. Short and intriguing story. The Top 10 reviews pretty much have everything else covered. It's different.. in a good way.

This game is fantastic, in short. It takes the standard RTS genre and adds and modifies a lot of elements that make it a very unique game. Content is added with good pacing, and the game sticks to its core mechanics without feeling 'samey.'  The graphics are very cool and definitely feel inspired by Tron.  Each of the enemy units is unique, engaging, and fun to fight.  It's not without its flaws. The camera can be pretty wonky at times, aiming at flying units is a pain in the butt, and sometimes the Darwinians are really hard to corral, to name a few.  Still, definitely a game worth picking up and playing. I highly recommend it!
A wonderfully retro RTS, plays like 'War games', the ZX Spectrum and C&C had a baby

i suspect i probably got this game 11 years too late. i just can't bring myself to accept the controls of this game now, where 11 years ago, i would've played this for non-stop.  I recommend this for people who wants a new RTS, although, i'm tempted to say, I'd rather re-play total annhiliation instead.
